docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 U.S. Diplomat Is Slain Outside His Home in Jordan A senior American diplomat, Laurence Foley, was gunned down outside his house, shot eight times at close range in what appeared to be the latest of a string of terror attacks against Western targets. Both the Jordanian government and the United States ambassador refused to comment on the perpetrators or motive for the assassination. A1 Warnings From Russia President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia was prepared to strike at international terrorist groups in whatever country harbors them. Speaking in the aftermath of the siege of a Moscow theater by Chechen guerrillas, Mr. Putin ordered the Russian military to draft a new doctrine adapting its forces and tactics to meet terrorist threats. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN legislation making it easier for the United States to enter new free-trade agreements was passed last summer, reactions were black and white. President Bush called the trade promotion authority bill, formerly known as ''fast track,'' ''a victory for the American economy'' and dreamed aloud of free trade pacts with Chile, Singapore, Australia and Morocco, the nations of southern Africa and the democracies of the Western Hemisphere. The President sees trade as a means of increasing exports and creating more than enough jobs to compensate for those that will inevitably be lost to foreign imports.

headline.main: Global Trade in Elmwood Park: Familiar Saga With a Twist

docs.abstract: Article on impact of free trade accords on labor market within United States; Pres Bush sees free trade as means of increasing exports and creating more than enough jobs to compensate for those that will inevitably be lost to foreign imports; unions doubt that; AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney calls free-trade agreements 'blank check' to send good jobs overseas; picture from Elmwood Park, NJ, is mixed after JVC Corp closes its plant to move it overseas and Marcal Paper Mills takes over site to expand its business; photos (Special Section, Working) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau County legislators late tonight adopted a $2.3 billion budget for 2003 that raises county property taxes by nearly 20 percent and cuts the work force by 1,400 jobs as the first chapter of a four-year plan to rescue the county from near-bankruptcy. The approval of the budget and the longer-range plan was a victory for County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi, a Democrat who took over on Jan. 1 promising to solve the fiscal crisis he inherited from the prior Republican administration. Since 2000, Nassau has been operating under a state-imposed fiscal review board and with state aid, which is estimated to be more than $70 million next year.

headline.main: Nassau Raises Property Tax By 20% in Its New Budget

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES a job pays well but perhaps not well enough. While other health care positions go begging because nurses and others feel that they are being paid too little to care for too many patients, pharmacy has generally been viewed as a lucrative and attractive profession. But many hospitals and clinics, in addition to drugstores and retailers, are struggling to find pharmacists. Although pharmacists, even right out of school, can earn about $80,000 a year, industry executives say it remains a challenge to find licensed people. There are about 200,000 licensed pharmacists in the United States. About two-thirds fill prescriptions and dispense advice to patients in drugstores, supermarkets or other retailers. An additional 25 percent work in hospitals and nursing homes. An increasing number are women, many of whom prefer to work part time.

headline.main: Available Spaces Behind The Prescription Counter

docs.abstract: Many hospitals and clinics, in addition to drugstores and retailers, are struggling to find pharmacists; although pharmacists, even right out of school, can earn $80,000 a year, industry executives say it remains challenge to find licensed people at time when more prescriptions are being written, result of large aging population and increasing availability of more medications; pharmacy can take as long as six years to train for the profession, and there is widespread concern that pharmacists have little opportunity to advance; photo (Special Section, Working) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that it would lose at least 530,000 members this year and surrender its longstanding position as the nation's third-largest health insurer. By January, Cigna will cover fewer than 12.7 million people, well behind UnitedHealth Group, which has 16.2 million, and Aetna, with 14.4 million. It will also trail Wellpoint Health Networks, which recently grew to 13.1 million members.

headline.main: Cigna to Feel Major Loss In Customers

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 15th century, Portugal's empire straddled the globe, and Lisbon was one of the most important trading posts in Europe, revered for its explorers. The city center was destroyed by an earthquake in 1755 and later rebuilt by the Marquês de Pombal. He lent his name to Baixa Pombalina, the city's commercial hub, which retains much of its original character: narrow streets, wrought-iron balconies and tiled facades. Portugal joined the European Community in 1986 and held a $2 billion international fair in 1998 -- an event that Lisbon used to refurbish historic buildings, build the 10-mile-long Vasco da Gama Bridge over the Tagus River, overhaul the riverfront area and generally let the world know that it was a contender. It is a small city, with a population of 700,000, and is easy to navigate on foot, public transportation and car -- a sort of Boston on the Tagus.

headline.main: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Lisbon; An Accessible City With an Empire in Its Past

docs.lead_paragraph: When the stock market was riding high, Cigna bet that the gains would continue forever. Now that its wager has backfired, it is scrambling to put its balance sheet in adequate shape while its shareholders suffer. Cigna disclosed yesterday that by the end of the year it will be more leveraged than it wants to be, and said that was one reason it had called off plans to borrow about $200 million. But Cigna said it did not expect to have to issue common stock.

headline.main: Market Place; Cigna's Plan For Buyback Has Created Cash Squeeze

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp's plan for stock buyback has created cash squeeze; discloses that by end of year it will be more leveraged than it wants to be, and says that is one reason it has called off plans to borrow about $200 million; says it does not expect to have to issue common stock; Cigna's decision to buy its shares looks bad because share price has fallen; one reason price has fallen is that Cigna bet against stock market plunge; chart (Market Place column) (M)
